Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 08:28AM momzr wrote: My case I feel is similar to yours.  I am 46 and they found a tiny area of DCIS I had in July during surgical biopsy due to cluster of microcalcifications spotted on annual digital mammo in June.  My DCIS was 1.6 mm in size, clear margins, no necrosis present, cribriform/solid, intermediate nuclear grade.  When I met with radiation oncologist, he originally was leaning toward need for radiation treatment.  However, after a long discussion of questions and concerns I had he ended up saying he did NOT feel he would recommend radiation treatment provided I was very vigilant about follow up mammograms and MRI's if necessary.  I had asked him if I were his wife if he would give me radiation treatments and he said honestly if I were his wife he would NOT treat me.  I also had met with a medical oncologist prior to seeing radiation oncologist and he was very emphatic that he did not think with my tiny tumor that I would need radiation or hormone therapy and felt there was a very miniscule chance this would ever return invasively - that I was not to lose sleep over this or worry about it.  He, too, said that was the same recommendation he would give his wife.  I talked it over with my husband as well and he said if you can only have the radiation to your breast once he thought we should save the "big guns" for if I truly ever have something seriously wrong.   I'm sure I would have felt differently about going with recommendation of no radiation if my tumor had been much larger, if my margins had not been clear, if the cells were the more agressive (comedo) type, if my follow up MRI had indicated anything of concern, or if any part of it had been considered invasive.  That's my story . . . don't know that it helps your decision or not.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Rads for low-grade DCIS redheadace1 fullofquestions

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 06:19AM momzr wrote: I had a wire guided surgical biopsy/lumpectomy last July.  They numbed me up before inserting the wire and I did not feel it at all, so it was not bad for me.  They then taped the wire down on  the upper part of my chest.  I also looked at it after insertion and thought how strange it looked.  I told them I felt like I was now "Bionic Woman" and would I be able to leap tall buildings in a single bound??  They said they doubted that but that maybe I'd be able to pick up some radio signals - ha!  (My way of dealing with stuff is humor)  Anyhow, there was not much time for me between insertion and actual biopsy (probably less than an hour) which I was glad of because they had told me to be careful so that the wire wouldn't move out of position.  I don't know if they thought I was going to try and throw football passes while I was waiting or what - ha!  I remember sitting very carefully to try and not move wire at all as I thought I sure didn't want to have to go through this again!  It really was not 'bad' though and I could go through it again if I had to (crossing finger not!)  Good luck with yours!!
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: momzr wrote: My SIL called me this week to say she was going to have to have a breast biopsy also.  (I had a surgical biopsy back in July).  She is to have a stereotactic biopsy.  This was what they originally wanted to do with me, however, I was too small for it to work as a stereotactic and they ended up having to do a wire-guided biopsy instead. Anyhow . . . she shared with me that when she went back to breast center she had her original digial mammogram at that they had her lay on the stereotactic table and tried a number of times to view the calcifications but were not having a lot of luck and said rather than attempt it they would wait six months and re-evaluate.  She decided to get a second opinion at another local hospital and is rescheduled for a stereotactic this coming Friday at the second hospital.  The interesting thing is that at this SECOND hospital that they told her they also had troubles with their stereotactic equipment once they went to digital mammograms and the stereotactic (which is essentially also a mammogram I guess - just done in a different manner) equipment they originally had wasn't one that could 'keep up' with the new digital mammography and made it difficult to spot calcifications, etc., so they have a NEW stereotactic biopsy table that I guess is more 'up-to-date' with the digital technology.  Just an FYI that women having stereotactic biopsies suggested after digital mamm's might want to ask how 'current' the stereotactic equipment is at the breast center, because I guess this can be a problem. I am personally glad she went for that second opinion and will go ahead and have it looked at before another six months just to set her mind at ease. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Biopsy machines/digital mamm's momzr momzr

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 01:25PM momzr wrote: My story is somewhat similar to yours.  In 2008 I had just turned 46 (also have really dense breasts) when had a mammo showing pleomorphic characteristics in microcalcs (DCIS).  Last summer another 'scare' with more microcalcifications in left breast (completely benign conditions associated this time).  The ones I had removed last summer spanned a distance of about 8-9 mm, so a pretty small area, but I am pretty small in the bustline anyhow (not even an A cup).  The nurse practitioner who I met with as well also shared with me there are three 'classifications' of microcalc's.  Benign (of course nothing to worry about), Indeterminite (which is what mine last summer were classified as), and Pleomorphic (more ofen times a definite problem).  Three years ago the ones I had removed which did turn out to be 1.6 mm of DCIS were classified as 'mildly pleomorphic' in appearance and also listed as a 'cluster' which on mamm films did look somewhat circular and close together.  Last summer the description on radiologist report who read mammogram called them a 'grouping of indeterminite calcifications' and they looked a bit more 'scattered' to me and not as close together as the DCIS diagnosis had been and  they turned out to be nothing. I will just go back to regular mammogram screenings again this coming summer as directed by Breast Surgeon.  I am hoping for no problems and maybe somewhat less dense breasts as I have now gone over a year without a period which I think means "official menopause" and I thought after menopause that your breasts can be 'less dense'.
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications - Biopsy Monday Butterflylady2012 Moderators

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 11:27PM momzr wrote: Here is a good website I came across with a LOT of information on calcifications.  Maybe there is some info in it that can help you understand microcalc's better.  I had a biopsy back in July '08 and the microcalcifications I had were ALL related to b9 conditions.  Here is website: http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53
Posts.Title: Are microcalcifications pre cancerous? naturegirl2 flowingspirit

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 09:24AM momzr wrote: If what they were recommending to her was a stereotactic biopsy, I DID have this same situation happen to me last summer (July '08).  When they spotted microcalcification cluster on digital mammogram (my first digital BTW, after six years of the other type).  The day of my mammogram they explained they would send me for a 'fitting' on the stereotactic as I am very small breasted (probably not even a full "A" cup!) and they weren't sure that stereo would really work for me.  They found that I did not have enough breast tissue to do the steretactic procedure.  My cluster was behind the nipple of my left breast and the tech showed me the needle they use in the procedure and said I would look like a shish kabob as the needle would go right through the breast since I did not have a lot of breast tissue.  SOOO I had a surgical biopsy instead.  In the long run it was best anyhow as they are able to take out 'suspicious' area as well as as much surrounding tissue as they think is necessary once they go in.  I think numerous times people who have the stereo procedure end up with a surgical biopsy later in the game anyhow, so, for me personally, it was just as well I started at that step to begin with.  I DO think you need to be a certain size for the stereotactic equipment to be successful and I think in general if you are small breasted it doesn't work very well.
Posts.Title: Too small for needle biopsy? Leah_S momzr

Posts.Content: momzr wrote: I came across an article/website I thought was quite informative about breast calcifications.  It might help some of you who have had calcifications show up on your mammogram, especially if you have the report from your mammogram that might describe how the calcifications looked.  Here is the website/article http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breast calcifications article momzr leaf

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 10:22AM momzr wrote: Here is my experience with "indeterminate" - not that this will necessarily be the same as what your wife will experience.  Just sharing my situation.  In 2008 I had just turned 46 when had a mammo showing pleomorphic characteristics in microcalcs (DCIS). Summer of 2009 another 'scare' with more microcalcifications in left breast (completely benign conditions associated this time).  The ones I had removed summer of 2009 spanned a distance of about 8-9 mm, so a pretty small area, but I am pretty small in the bustline anyhow (not even an A cup).  The nurse practitioner who I met with shared with me there are three 'classifications' of microcalc's.  Benign (of course nothing to worry about), Indeterminite (which is what mine summer of 2009 were classified as and what it appears your wife has been classifed with), and Pleomorphic (more ofen times a definite problem).  In 2008 the ones I had removed which did turn out to be 1.6 mm of DCIS were classified as 'mildly pleomorphic' in appearance and also listed as a 'cluster' which on mamm films did look somewhat circular and close together. Summer of 2009 the description on radiologist report who read mammogram called them a 'grouping of indeterminite calcifications' and they looked a bit more 'scattered' to me and not as close together as the DCIS diagnosis had been and they turned out to be nothing. I have had an additional stereotactic biopsy on microcalc's again in summer of 2011 and these were also 'benign'.  Since that time, my mamm's have remained 'stable' and unchanged and I continue to have either six month or annual screenings.  Good luck to your wife!
Posts.Title: Cluster of microcalcifications rajchat rajchat

Posts.Content: momzr wrote: Monday I went for my 4th Breast MRI.  I have had these annually since my diagnosis of DCIS in July of 2008.  When the MRI tech was talking to me about it he was saying how he thinks they are better because they get a much better look at the soft tissue (and obviously breasts are 'soft tissue').  My DCIS in July of 2008 was 1.6 mm (so quite a teeny tiny amount) and I asked him how small the 'slices' are for the MRI's and he told me they go as small as 3 mm slices, however, when I was finished he did say he was able to do them as small as 1 mm.  I was glad to hear that it goes that small for evaulation.  The MRI was fine BTW, nothing abnormal or suspicious seen in it and I have mammograms as well every summer so two tests are run each year on my crazy dense/cyst filled breasts (I had nothing other than the excisional biopsy for my DCIS, no rad's or tamoxifin or anything else, so really want to stay on top of screenings).  I do have to get insurance 'approval' to have the MRI's, but that wasn't an issue.  I feel better having both mamm's and MRI's done yearly also.  Just sharing my experience. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breast MRI/soft tissue momzr KellyMaryland

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 09:59AM momzr wrote: I am also in the contstant 'callback' club.  Unfortunately, I believe the way insurance works is, in general, you must have the regular "screening" mamm before you can get to the 'diagnostic' (where radiologist will look it over before you leave screening center thus avoiding a 'callback').  I started getting mamm's with a baseline at 37 yrs (I had reached my deductible that year) and then annually at age 40.  I just turned 50 this summer and so in 12 years of mamm's I would say I have been called back 70-75% of the time.  There may have been 2 or 3 years when I did not have to go back for 'additional views'.  I, too, am very tired of it, BUT glad that the majority of the time it seems to be nothing.   While it is super annoying I would rather go through additional testing to be certain things are 'nothing to worry about'.
Posts.Title: Would like for just 1 time to not have to get called back clevelandgirl99 Infobabe

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 02:38PM momzr wrote: When I had my excisional biopsy, the surgeon told me they should have results within three days.  I had my excisional on a Tuesday, and late Friday afternoon, I got a call from the breast surgeon's nurse to tell me the pathology had indicated a small amount of DCIS.  My breast surgeon said they would call as soon as they know because he knows how people are waiting on pins and needles for news like that.  I appreciated being called rather than waiting for a follow up appointment to hear the news.
Posts.Title: If cancer, do they call me??? jjjmjoh I_am_4_GOD

Posts.Title: "Booklet" on pathology report momzr gemsa

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 12:55PM momzr wrote: I do think if your BIRADS classification is a "4" there is always a recommendation for biopsy.  I, too, had microcalcifications as sort of a 'red flag' in July 2008 and ended up with excisional biopsy/lumpectomy on my left breast and my biopsy did turn out to have a small DCIS tumor in the biopsy (1.6 mm), however, it was considered an 'incidental find' and was not actually in the exact area of the microcalcifications themselves.  As I mentioned before, my surgeon at appt. prior to biopsy kept stressing that 80% of them are benign, so my husband and I felt good about that even though mine did end up having that tiny amt. of DCIS.  More often than not, it ends up being some sort of benign reason!  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Bilateral Breast Biopsies jojo0624 tboskin

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 09:51AM momzr wrote: Hello jojo -- I actually think that calcifications in both breasts is quite common and many women have biopsies to investigate them.  I know that I have many calcifications in both breasts, but most of them are not calcifications that look concerning to the radiologists at my annual mammograms.  You do not mention whether these were 'microcalcifications' that were biopsied, but I suspect they may have been because it seems to be if they are 'micro' or 'clustered' or arranged in a certain way when they are suggested for biopsy.  Here is a link to breast calcification information which I think may give you more than you really need, but when you have your pathology report back or even if you have a report from your last mammogram, you might look at how the calicifications were described in the wording and this may help you to know more.  http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 Good luck with the test results . . . remember that 80% of calicifications DO turn out to have benign results!
Posts.Title: Bilateral Breast Biopsies jojo0624 tboskin
